The publication date of the article, highlighting ongoing public scrutiny and debate over the funding model of the White House ballroom project.

keyTakeAways: The new $250 million White House ballroom is being funded through donations from wealthy individuals and corporations, sparking ethical concerns about 'pay-to-play' arrangements.
YouTube has pledged $22 million as part of a settlement with Trump over the suspension of its account after the January 6 Capitol riot, making it the only confirmed donor.

A dinner on 15 October featured executives from companies including Blackstone, OpenAI, Microsoft, Coinbase, Palantir, Lockheed Martin, Amazon, and Google, as well as NFL owners Woody Johnson and the Glazers of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Manchester United.
Donors may receive public recognition, such as names etched into the ballroom, raising questions about transparency and potential influence.
Legal experts, like Richard Painter, argue that the funding model may constitute an ethics violation by using access to the White House as a fundraising tool.
The White House claims the renovation will not cost taxpayers a cent and that the ballroom will be used by future administrations, not just Trump's.
Martin Mongiello, a former White House executive chef, suggests the ballroom will eventually pay for itself by replacing expensive tent events.
The project's scale—originally planned for 650, now revised to 999 guests—amplifies concerns about political access and exclusivity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The construction of a $250 million new White House ballroom, set to host up to 999 guests, has raised serious ethical concerns about corporate and individual donations, with the White House claiming the project will not cost taxpayers. While YouTube has committed $22 million as part of a legal settlement, a list of other donors remains undisclosed. A dinner on 15 October brought together executives from major companies including Blackstone, OpenAI, Microsoft, and Google, as well as owners of NFL franchises. Critics, including former ethics lawyer Richard Painter, warn this could amount to a 'pay-to-play' scheme, where access to the White House is exchanged for financial support. The White House argues the ballroom will save costs by replacing expensive tent events and will be used by future administrations. However, the potential for political influence and lack of transparency continue to fuel public debate.
title: Who is paying for Donald Trump's new White House ballroom?
